description: From late 17th century French effronterie, from effronté (“shameless, insolent”), from Old French esfronté, from Vulgar Latin *exfrontātus. Compare Latin effrōns (“barefaced”), from the prefix ex- (“from”) + frōns (“forehead”) (English: front).

examples: We even had the effrontery to suggest that he should leave the country.

entries.meaning: (countable) An act of insolent and shameless audacity.
examples: Any refusal to salute the president shall be counted as an effrontery.
